entries.content: Present a list of common problems you solve to the prospect. If they don't recognize any, it indicates they likely don't have those specific issues.
entries.notes: Used to quickly identify if the prospect has the typical root causes for needing your solution.

entries.content: When a prospect doesn't recognize the problems you describe, ask clarifying questions to understand their situation and the root cause of why they don't have those problems.
entries.notes: Example questions: 'You don't have salespeople?', 'You don't have to prospect?'

entries.content: If a prospect doesn't recognize the problems you fix, you have nothing to lose by continuing to ask questions to find out what IS going on in their business.
entries.notes: Focus on understanding their reality, even if it doesn't fit your initial assumptions.

entries.content: Clarify what a business actually does if their initial description seems inconsistent or suggests they wouldn't need your service, to understand the root cause of the disconnect.
entries.notes: Example: Asking 'You just do marketing then, you don't sell events?' when they claim they don't sell.

focus_area: Objection Discovery: Clarifying questions, isolation, root cause
